There's slight problem that in next step [49](https://www.freecodecamp.org/learn/javascript-algorithms-and-data-structures-v8/learn-recursion-by-building-a-decimal-to-binary-converter/step-49), seed code has: `'a(): returns "freeCodeCamp " + b()'`. It'd be good to keep this consistent between steps.

Hi there,

Thanks for creating this pull request.

The linked issue has not been triaged yet, and a solution has not been agreed upon. Once the issue is open for contribution, you are welcome to update this pull request to reflect the issue consensus. Until the issue is open for contribution, we will not be able to review your pull request.
waiting for the approval and ready adjust if needed..

Hey there,

Thanks for your interest in contributing. We appreciate your efforts, but this PR doesn't follow [our guidelines](https://contribute.freecodecamp.org/how-to-open-a-pull-request).

Do not worry, you should join our [Discord](https://discord.gg/KVUmVXA) server and ask for help in the `#contributors` channel. That will help other contributors guide you to get your PR ready for a review. 

Happy Contributing!
As it is the lab can be completed with an invisible house. Should maybe ask for each item to have a border or background color?

This looks great! 
I think descriptions could become the place where we "show the explanation" and I agree these collapsible descriptions could be below the exercises. And, yes - we'd use them to all  tasks except the dialogues. Then we'd need to use an  #-- instructions-- section where we add explanation about the exercise. For the new blocks I'm working I'm already adding those. 

During our last meeting Tom mentioned we could use an alternative to adding html tags to the markdown. You might want to discuss that with him.
This is an automated response to help you with this issue. Please let us know if you need further assistance.

> I would like to see a little more directing users to play with the app.

Yeah I agree. I can update that üëç 

> Wonder if we should add the demoType: onLoad here? was that left out intentionally? It might help a bit.

I wasn't sure if that was only for labs but I can add that in

> On step 1, you could maybe describe the boilerplate given to them and tell them to look at it - and what functionality they will add.

We could do something similar to the current pyramid generator project where we give a brief intro into what they are going to do

https://www.freecodecamp.org/learn/javascript-algorithms-and-data-structures-v8/learn-introductory-javascript-by-building-a-pyramid-generator/step-1

We could explain what the boilerplate is there and encourage them to check it out before proceeding to the next step.

We could also do this for all DOM projects where the HTML and CSS is provided for them

> I wasn't sure if that was only for labs but I can add that in

Yea, the labs should have a `demoType` of `onClick` I believe - that will show the button to open the preview. And step-1 of the workshops should have a `demoType` of `onLoad` I believe (assuming we want it) - which opens the preview on that step. [See step-1 of the current quiz project](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/main/curriculum/challenges/english/14-responsive-web-design-22/learn-accessibility-by-building-a-quiz/614ccc21ea91ef1736b9b578.md) - and [see it in action](https://www.freecodecamp.dev/learn/2022/responsive-web-design/learn-accessibility-by-building-a-quiz/step-1)
I will work on applying the other changes tomorrow üëç

> The workshop is off to a good start Here is some early feedback from me üëç

Thank you. And sorry for bothering you. I should have converted the PR to a draft on time.

> Also, if I get around to it - the end goal might be to have a single view component that incorporates all these features.

I would love this.
It might be useful to add a comment on the attribute usage condition as it is a pretty niche solution.

> It might be useful to add a comment on the attribute usage condition as it is a pretty niche solution.

What about extracting the `!isMultifileCertProject && !projectBasedChallenge` into variable ie. `hasResizableCodePane`?
Sounds good, one suggestion would be `hasVerticalResizableCodePane`.
Don't merge until we confer with mobile.

> Second attempt at this.

Does this replace https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/pull/55884 or are you deciding between them?

It replaces it. The main difference being the way you create the questions in the markdown. The other one was to add another heading for each question, e.g: `--question1--`, `--question2--`, etc, along with the subheadings for each question. With this, you just need to add more sub-headings e.g: `--text--`, `-answers--`, `--video-solution--`

I'd agree with you @moT01, I did the same with the factorial calculator.
I have updated the tests and instructions to allow any parameter for the function.
This updates the challenge schema. Blocked while mobile takes a look - cc @freeCodeCamp/mobile

I'm not sure we have reached a consensus on this.

But no matter what, we should update the description to include information about the callback. Please refer back to the issue for the text.
@lasjorg thanks. Updated PR.
Yes, that is exactly what I mean!

Hello,

Firstly, thank you for submitting this pull request!

As you navigate through the process, we have a PR checklist to ensure consistency and quality in our contributions. We kindly ask that you genuinely follow through with each point. This not only facilitates the review process but also demonstrates a mutual respect for the community's efforts.

If you're unfamiliar with certain aspects, our [contributing guidelines](https://contribute.freecodecamp.org) are a helpful resource to get you up to speed.

<details>
<summary>**Friendly Pointers (click to expand)**</summary>

1. **Editing on GitHub:** While it's possible to edit files directly on GitHub, it's typically better not to. This helps avoid inadvertent mistakes like typos that can disrupt tests.

2. **Pull Request Title:** Please ensure the PR title follows [our convention](https://contribute.freecodecamp.org/how-to-open-a-pull-request/#prepare-a-good-pr-title).

3. **Linking Issues:** Please ensure you link issues using the designated method. Simply update the `XXXXXX` in the PR description to include the issue number. This keeps our records organized and clear.

4. **Engaging with the Team:** We know you're eager, but kindly keep mentions and review requests limited. Our maintainers are always on the lookout and will attend to PRs in the order they come in.

5. **Branch Management:** It's a good practice not to work directly off your `main` branch. Creating separate branches for different changes allows you to smoothly update your PR even as the main repository progresses.

</details>

Please note, there's no need to close this PR. If you have questions or need guidance refining your contribution, don't hesitate to ask. Our community is here to assist.

Thank you for your enthusiasm in contributing to our project. We eagerly await more contributions from you!

**Happy Contributing!** üåü

Daniel made that example of adding a speaking option in the challenges. I think that would be possible. Perhaps we can discuss it again on Monday.
I'll revisit this after https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/pull/55792 is in, since that touches a lot of the same code.

It is important to stay true to the docs here about the language used for step descriptions.

https://contribute.freecodecamp.org/how-to-work-on-coding-challenges/#challenge-descriptionsinstructions

In general, it is best to avoid first person language like  "I", ‚Äúwe‚Äù, ‚Äúlet‚Äôs‚Äù, and ‚Äúus‚Äù and instead use "you"

Hey, @ShaunSHamilton, as I said in the chat a while back, I think the terminology needs clarifying and writing down somewhere we can all refer to. 

As it stands it's very hard to parse the difference between NewQuestion, QuestionType, NewQuestionType, NewConfig, question_types inside new configs vs question_types in new exam and so on.

If we had a high-level terminology document, like we do for Workshop, Lecture, Lab and the like, then it shouldn't be too hard to disentangle these concepts.
I have renamed and added better documentation for the structs. So, hopefully that clears a lot of stuff up.

Thanks for the PR - I guess this doesn't really hurt anything, but this is not the solution discussed in the issue. I am going to close this for now, because I think the issue needs some more discussion. If you think I'm wrong, feel free to leave a message and we can revisit it.

Actually, I am going to open this back up. We can use this as a temporary solution while we figure out something better. We would need to add this note to all of the projects though. You should be able to do a search for `challengeType: 14` to find them all @nayelimdejesus. If you do that, I think we would be able to merge this.

> I think you changed the tests on 18 and 29 cause of the funny trick you found. Here's what GPT says:

That's the one!

> But the first test on those steps checks for the variable declaration - e.g. `const button2` which overwrites the global. So I didn't see why they needed to be changed.

It looks slightly like the best case scenario. The worst one is a bit nitpicking, but other test:
```js
assert.match(code, /const\s+button2/);
```
Would of course match `const button2something`. Only related test is changed, but it increases confidence for this one as well.

Edit: should be fixed now <s>Well, I might have jumped the shark on this. With very large fonts, there is an overflow on input-container at one point. I did move the MQ breakpoint, but I guess I didn't test it with very large fonts (or I added the monospace font after I had tested it). Also, it is a little wonky when the text starts to wrap before the inputs stack. I should probably move the break point up to 590px so it stacks sooner.</s>

wish list: should the stack have an open top? (no top border) and any chance the animation can move the blocks from the top to the bottom where they can rest? (like a more interesting animation). Just a wish list...

The stack can be open at the top, but most illustrations usually do not have that.

Adding animations would require more work. I'm guessing it would need to be done in the JS as part of the challenge. Adding it behind the scenes in pure CSS would be more difficult or have some potential timing jank.
There's a conflict here @patrickwcode, I think updating your branch will take care of it. Let me know if you want me to take a look.

1. Rebase my copy
2. Remove the conflicting files (`curriculum/i18n-curriculum`)
3. Push changes to PR

https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/pull/54983#issuecomment-2154546016
Is there anything else I need to do for this PR?

You have end to end tests that are failing. You see buddy pieces of code are linked to other pieces of the curriculum in ways that aren't always obvious at first. You see by changing the Cat Photo App solutions, some of the input for the end to end (spelled e2e)  tests need to be updated too. Does that make sense?
Do you want me to explain what you need to do to  the end to end tests?

Yes, please explain how to handle the e2e tests.

e2e tests for practice projects: Step x + step x solution code should equal step x + 1 seed code.

Okay the lower-jar.spec.ts and progress-bar.spec.ts files uses the Cat Photo App project to verify if the code submissions are able to go through. As you updated the solutions, the solutions need updated in the test code. 

One of the tests in the lower-jar.spec.ts that need updated

https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/43e902dd85a1b9526bcc76e2d6330a1624258406/e2e/lower-jaw.spec.ts#L101-L129

A test in progress-bar.spec.ts that needs updated

https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/43e902dd85a1b9526bcc76e2d6330a1624258406/e2e/progress-bar.spec.ts#L7-L35

Could it have anything to do with this?:

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d00cfe06-1dd4-4b11-a498-31c3f34a70e4)

I found the problem. You see that challenge wasn't added to the seeded user. Unfortunately for the progress bar, it expects the cat photo app to be at 100% completion. As you added a challenge, it wasn't complete any more. 

That does raise the question what other kinds of things aren't in the seed code anymore.

Here is roughly around where you need to insert content. 

https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/40ad1a6667495efcee362899d843d16856976254/tools/scripts/seed/user-data.js#L4509-L4513 

And the following should be added:

```JS
 {
        id: '668bae23be54d01f57738a11',
        completedDate: 1689770484197,
        files: []
},
```

This adds the id of your challenge onto the list of completed challenges.  I'd like the data to be near the rest of the challenge ids for the Cat Photo App if possible.  Insert the data without deleting, as you added a challenge.

> Could it have anything to do with this?:

that is not related to the failing test, but you need to solve the merge conflict too

> There shouldn't be any changes to the `curriculum/i18n-curriculum` on this PR. Try running `git submodule update --init` when you have your PR checked out.

I ran the code with the PR checked out and committed an empty commit, no joy.

I pushed a fix @Supravisor. This is what I did:

cd curriculum/i18n-curriculum
git checkout 2eeff0 (the hash of where the submodule was at when you made this PR)
cd ../.. (back to main freeCodeCamp repo folder)
git add
git commit

Okay we have an existing syntax error message. Should that error output be modified (and the behavior of our Python code that logs to the console as well as the preview); or would it be better to just use a new error output?
I meant to push days ago but it never actually went out. I don't think I did something quite right though.

We've discussed this a little internally and I think what we need is something like this:

If there's a syntax error and the tests are failing show a message to the learner asking them to check the console

The message telling the learner to check the console should appear in the lower jaw, either as part of the hint or as an additional hint.

Finally, the syntax error should appear at the top of the console when tests run.
I think because I stopped tests from running after a failure , this was a bad implementation.

MDN is a good accessibility reference, but it is not authoritative. In this case, I don't think MDN is giving you all of the options for managing focus in a modal dialog. You don't have to place the focus on an element in the dialog, you can place it on the dialog itself. Oh, actually, I just checked, and the [MDN page for the dialog element](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/dialog#accessibility) does actually suggest this.

I'm apparently not smart enough to trigger these modals so I can't give you my opinion on where focus should be placed. I just wanted to let you know that it doesn't have to be on either of these buttons.

Thanks @bbsmooth!

You can open the modal manually in the local environment by setting `open={true}`:

https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/blob/6faca2af885f3b2c39cd18554732639102c3e6f9/client/src/components/Donation/donation-modal.tsx#L68

But if you're on production, you can trigger the modal by completing three challenges.

--- 

There is also a guide that W3 provides: https://www.w3.org/WAI/ARIA/apg/patterns/dialog-modal/. The doc says we can even place the focus on the text content, rather than a focusable element. But I wasn't sure if that's the case here, since the context is clear enough.

> If the dialog content includes semantic structures, such as lists, tables, or multiple paragraphs, that need to be perceived in order to easily understand the content, i.e., if the content would be difficult to understand when announced as a single unbroken string, then it is advisable to add `tabindex="-1"` to a static element at the start of the content and initially focus that element. This makes it easier for assistive technology users to read the content by navigating the semantic structures. Additionally, it is advisable to omit applying `aria-describedby` to the dialog container in this scenario.

https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/issues/50184

I've made a slight adjustment to the HTTP status codes in the project progress reset functionality to better align with how we're handling responses.

Successful Reset Status Code Update: Previously, when a reset operation was successful, we were using a 204 No Content status code. While this accurately represented the idea that the operation doesn't need to return any content, it did pose some limitations on providing feedback to the client, particularly about what was done. So, I've updated this to use a 202 Accepted status code. This change allows us to include a response body with message and devMessage, improving the feedback loop to our clients about the reset operation's success, especially useful for logging and debugging purposes.

No Challenges to Reset Status Code Change: For scenarios where the reset request is valid, but there are no challenges to reset (because the user hasn't completed any in the requested blocks), previously used a 202 Accepted. To make our response more intuitive and to clearly indicate that the request was processed successfully but resulted in no operational changes, I've shifted this to a 200 OK status code. It's a subtle change that helps clarify the outcome was as expected, just without any action needed.

For other reviewers: Every time I test this, I forget what is necessary to make requests. So, here is the format:

```bash
curl 'http://localhost:3000/account/reset-progress' \
-X 'DELETE' -d '{"blocks": ["block-dashed-name"]}' \
-H 'content-type: application/json' \
-H 'cookie: jwt_access_token=token-value; _csrf=token-value; csrf_token=token-value; connect.sid=taoken-value;' \
-H 'csrf-token: token-value'
```

I also have a somehow related frontend PR [#54028](https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/pull/54028).

6. **Messaging for No Challenges Reset:**

Best regards,

3. The issue with this is that the certification projects are required to claim a certification. Here's [one of mine](https://www.freecodecamp.org/certification/mot01/responsive-web-design) - the projects I submitted to earn it are at the bottom. With the current implementation, if we reset a block with any of those cert projects, the project(s) submitted will be lost, but the certification will still be claimed. We like to keep the projects people submitted so we can validate them if needed. I listed two options in my review. I think we should see what some others say on this.

4. I think you should be able to just delete from those two arrays in the same way you did with `completedChallenges` - e.g:

```
$pull: {
  completedChallenges: { id: { $in: toResetChallengeIds } },
  savedChallenges: { id: { $in: toResetChallengeIds } },
  partiallyCompletedChallenges: { id: { $in: toResetChallengeIds } },
}
```

5. I'm not sure on this one either. I think we are probably fine with just returning the messages for now and letting the clients handle it. Maybe others can weigh in.

6. I saw this multiple times with multiple different blocks. This was one: `body: {"blocks": ["learn-greetings-in-your-first-day-at-the-office"]}`

7. I think tests are important cause they verify that the endpoint is doing what's expected and also let others know what the endpoint is doing. There's some examples you can [follow in here.](https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/freeCodeCamp/tree/main/api-server/src/server/boot_tests) I would lean towards adding them, but perhaps we can defer until the new API.

Sorry for the delay, @RavidYael :cold_sweat:. I do agree with Tom, though: while names like `challengesWithCompleted` are rather ugly, they are more accurate than `progressionNodes`. The problem is "Node" doesn't really mean anything as far as the UI is concerned it only has meaning in the context of a graphQL query. I appreciate that we've mixed these up numerous times in the code base, but I'd rather we removed the other instances rather than added more.

As for Tile, it seems fine to use that for a UI component, but not for data. For example the type `ProgressionTilesWithCompleted` doesn't make sense to me, since it has no intrinsic connection to Tiles. It just happens that some data with that type is going to passed into them as a prop. In contrast, I like the tile components challenge-tile.tsx and challenge-tiles-list because it's clear what they are.

And, finally, maybe we want to put the Tiles in https://github.com/freeCodeCamp/ui, maybe we don't. However, I take back my previous comment. We can decide the best place for them later, there's no need to hold up this PR while we decide.
